subject: Re: Looking for a JUnit diff and trend analysis tool
msgSnippet: Hi David, I have started to write a tool by myself. I m parsing the junitreport XML file generated by ant using Castor. Castor is also used as a JDO/OR-mapping
messageBody:
Hi David,

I have started to write a tool by myself.
I'm parsing the junitreport XML file generated by ant using Castor.
Castor is also used as a JDO/OR-mapping tool to write/read data from
the underlying MySQL database. It looks quite promising.
I have now started to create a Swing GUI as the central user
interface for this tool. So, I'm able to mark different junitreport
results with a label that identifies the JVM, Operating system and
integration build number (together with the subversion/Clearcase
label) used to run the tests.
For trend analysis I will generate charts using JFreeChart or
StyleReportPro.

--Klaus

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kamal2222ahmed" <Kamal.Ahmed@w...>
wrote:
> > > Klaus,
> > >
> > > I wrote a hack for something like this a while ago, but it was
> optimized
> > > for looking at failing tests over hundreds of program versions,
> parsed
> > > from text output files. I imagine that you could probably
write
> > > something to do this yourself as quickly as extracting the
> interesting
> > > parts from my code.
> > >
> > > Can you give a few details about what you would be looking for
in a
> > > trend analysis? Thanks,
> > >
> > > David Saff
> > >
> > > kp.berg wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > >>Hi all,
> > >>
> > >>I know, JUnit 'unit' tests should always pass ;-) But we are
using the
> > >>JUnit framework to write integration and systemtests as well.
So from
> > >>time to time, in this area something may go wrong. Therefore
I'm
> > >>looking for a tool, that generates a report showing only the
> > >>differences between current and last JUnit report - which
failing
> > >>tests were fixed, which tests stopped to pass, which tests
were added
> > >>and which removed. Additionaly a test trend analysis should be
> > >>possible.
> > >>
> > >>I know, parsing the XML junitreport output and generating the
info,
> > >>e.g., with the help of a database, would be possible. But is
anyone
> > >>aware of an existing tool or open source project that can help
in this
> > >>direction?
> >
>
>
> Is there such a tool for eclipse/perforce?
>
